user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_SHA256_init:
```c
void
MHD_SHA256_init (struct Sha256Ctx *ctx)
{
  /* Initial hash values, see FIPS PUB 180-4 paragraph 5.3.3 */
  /* First thirty-two bits of the fractional parts of the square
   * roots of the first eight prime numbers: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13,
   * 17, 19." */
  ctx->H[0] = UINT32_C (0x6a09e667);
  ctx->H[1] = UINT32_C (0xbb67ae85);
  ctx->H[2] = UINT32_C (0x3c6ef372);
  ctx->H[3] = UINT32_C (0xa54ff53a);
  ctx->H[4] = UINT32_C (0x510e527f);
  ctx->H[5] = UINT32_C (0x9b05688c);
  ctx->H[6] = UINT32_C (0x1f83d9ab);
  ctx->H[7] = UINT32_C (0x5be0cd19);

  /* Initialise number of bytes. */
  ctx->count = 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function MHD_SHA256_init:
struct Sha256Ctx
{
  uint32_t H[SHA256_DIGEST_SIZE_WORDS];     /**< Intermediate hash value / digest at end of calculation */
  uint32_t buffer[SHA256_BLOCK_SIZE_WORDS]; /**< SHA256 input data buffer */
  uint64_t count;                           /**< number of bytes, mod 2^64 */
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
void
MHD_SHA256_init (struct Sha256Ctx *ctx)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: MHD_SHA256_init writes to members of *ctx (ctx->H[...] and ctx->count) to initialize the context, so the pointer must be non-const. Rule 8.13 recommends const-qualified pointers when possible, but here const is not possible because the function modifies the object.
